>>27749060
Psych Major who plans on becoming a psychiatrist here:
It'd probably be a good idea to seek a psychiatrist for an evaluation of clinical depression. There are a variety of treatments which may help you, so discuss your options with the professional you work with. Usually, the best treatment is a combination of psychotherapy with medication (psychotherapy aids in treating the root of the problem while medication can help alleviate the symptoms of depression, thereby making it easier to treat the core issue). If you aren't prone to seizures and don't have epilepsy, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may also be useful (it's fast acting, and essentially 'reboots' your brain with a controlled shock). With that said, you don't necessarily need medication to treat depression, but it can make things easier.
Again, the best thing to do is get evaluated, ask as many questions as you can about your treatment plan, consider your options, and undergo treatment.

Firstly are you actually taking care of you teeth? Are you brushing 2 times day and flossing? Because if you aren't then brush your teeth.


And Go go a low cost dental clinic.

Don't remove a tooth yourself. Dentists actually need to fill the "leftover hole" of the removed tooth with "Bone filler". You can't just have a hole where your tooth used to be sitting empty. It needs to be filled with something.

Google "low cost dental clinic" and find one in your area.

If you don't have one nearby then search for cheap online dental insurance. Sometimes states offer ones for free to low income people

If your state doesn't, then It's usually $30 a month for cheapest dental insurance. Buy it. Wait 1 to 2 weeks for the paperwork to go through. Then go see a Dentist.

You really only need to pay for 2 or 3 months. Then cancel. Your dental once you get your procedure done.

You remind me of a girl I used to date. She looked good (even great in her better days), had a very personal sense of fashion and a creative disposition. She liked writing, drawing, dancing, going for long walks and reading. But years of failed connections, bulling and her own personal issues had left her with very bad socializing skills, so she didn’t really know how to present herself to other people. And because of her inability to keep a proper social circle she was not fully aware of her own awkwardness. She only knew that, at some point, people just ghosted her. No matter what, people ghosted her. And that reinforced the self-fulfilling nature of her social interactions, because she internalized that every new person would inevitably drop her.
It wasn’t until I got access to her writings that I realized the depth of her drive for discovering love, and how that conditioned her worldview. Everything in life was perfunctory but love, and even her creative processes were just a vehicle for the exploration of what being in love with somebody was.
But that was the problem. She wanted so much to feel and share that pure, blissful connection that it drove people away. It wasn’t that she was openly clingy or anything like that; it was just a vibe emanating from her that people picked up. Like a primordial directive telling them to stay away. And from what you have said, I wonder if you emanate the same kind of vibe.
Anyway, you said that you work in art projects. What kind of projects are those?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27748810
Those are vague reasons. You need to really consider the circumstances and see if they tried their best or just used you to make themselves feel better.
My parents mentally and physically abused me. Beat the shit out of me, called me stupid/ugly/retarded and not once even said anything positive about me throughout my entire childhood. I spent my entire 20s thinking about it deeply and couldn't really understand why I resented them. After I moved out, graduated college and became more independent, they were nice to me and we were on good terms (or so I thought). But I realized in one moment of clarity that the reason I resent them isn't because they didn't know how to be good parents, but because they've actively used the abuse to make up for their own shortcomings. My dad would beat me whenever his career or personal plans didn't go well and he needed to retain a sense of masculinity, and my mom would do it whenever she was angry with my dad and needed to vent out frustration.
I considered those good enough reasons for me to cut them off completely. I know they regret it because they do try to reach out often but I have so much anger at them that I don't feel bad about it. I have lost my teens and my 20s being anxious, paranoid and depressed because of them.

OP, think deeply and in length at how your parents behaved and why. If it was because they were just clueless, then learn to forgive them. If what they have done was because they needed to feel better about themselves, then think of how you go your own way. It's not easy though

you could try to sell most of the stuff at slightly lower market price (so you can do it fast) and left it as cash for your family to find, dead people still have expenses (trip to your location, coffins, burring/cremating, some weird tax, etc). it won't make them feel better but it will help with some of the expenses at least.

tl.dr: quit smoking weed, it's easier than I thought but I don't feel happier.

I quit smoking weed about a month ago after about a decade of near-daily use, though only after work. It wasn't really a conscious decision to quit. I just ran out, went on vacation, came back, and didn't bother to get some new stash, so decided to give it a try. No real withdrawal, so that's a plus.

Smoking never really impacted my life too much, and the expense was about 100 bucks a month, so nothing major.

On days I'm not hanging out with my friends, I feel bored now in the evenings. The music doesn't sound as great as it used to, I don't play piano as well as I did before, etc.. The upside is I spend more time cooking decent food and I'm slightly better at doing chores, although I have cleaning help so it never got really bad in the first place. The greatest advantage is that I sleep better and I feel (and look!) noticeably less tired.

On the other hand, I simply feel less happy than I was being a functioning addict, and knowing that over ten years it never really got out of hand (I don't use other drugs, never smoked a regular cigarette in my life, I have a social life, good career, etc...), I just feel like going back to the old ways. This is obviously the addiction speaking, so I'd love to hear your thoughts.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Where does confidence come from? I can point to things about myself that make me self-conscious. But I know people who have the traits I want who are insecure, and I know people who share the same traits as me who are confident. Where does it come from?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27747380
>short, small frame

I have known people like this who were in management or owned their own business. They were married and had children. They were very confident and could have conversations with just about anyone. They didn't let their looks affect their confidence at all. I'm sure deep down we all have insecurities, but it's okay as long as you have enough confidence to balance it out.

Regarding being emotional, I would work on that first. Making decisions with your emotions is one of the worst things you can do at work, so it's typically detrimental to getting successful with your career or finances. Likewise, being financially successful or having a job you know you can do well will give you confidence.

When I suggest taking risks, I mean managed risks. Don't take risks impulsively. Think them through and make sure you are prepared to take that risk. Again, don't make critical decisions with your emotions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27746331
If you're dumb they come easy. If you have any ambition you will have moments of self doubt and lack of confidence. Only way to gain it is to count your successes and learn from your failures.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27747397
>I stopped caring about impressing them

Another important tip for OP: NEVER make decisions based on trying to impress others. Your only obligation is to impress yourself.

If you are solely motivated by what other people think of you, then you will never be confident because you are judging yourself based on the minds of others which you can never really know. This leads to uncertainty which leads to fear.

I'm not saying that you should always disagree with others. But if you agree with someone else's opinion, make sure that it's because you decided that for yourself and not because you are trying to impress the other person.
